document.title: Early Childhood Standards of Quality for Birth to Kindergarten

2C2C15DA47C94E5AA7D5803B700DBC3C.description: Collect leaves and sort by type of tree and/or leaf shapes.

8DA461416590432E994208A0DB8CAA3C.description: Sort manipulatives into separate containers during clean up time.

EEB90588188A4C138A9F9445324C84C7.description:
Organize buttons based on different attributes, such as solid color, stripes,
dots.

05FE2AAF658746B8B8B1129AF868C17F.description:
Sort animals by habitat (farm or forest, for example), when directed by an
adult.

3BC6A1A9BB3F4FE78E339AC5108EDA32.description:
Sort blocks by material (plastic/wooden) during clean-up time, when directed
by an adult.

883C846FE0744FF8A52FF1D2A07EE3C0.description: Sort things in their environment into groups based on attributes.

11C02FB3FDE948818D922DC65E087350.description:
Classify items by their similarities, such as “all of these animals have fur, and
these ones over here have scales!”

3827CC3CB231498B9D56CEA722D7B404.description: Measure the growth of their seedling every day.

ABB1B331C4A54F77945B7B5E7F35B123.description:
Chart different kinds of weather with their group over the course of a week or
a month.

10AB4302300942AFA260FCF2F55A7228.description:
Ask the other children if they have a cat at home and make marks in their
journal to count how many.

897741CF6BE2417E9C059686335782AF.description:
Describe the similarities and differences between objects, such as
determining by feel that some of a collection of buttons are fabric-covered
and others have holes.

62071A89EEC34FEC99E53DF26F22686E.description:
Participate in a group activity to count how many people in the group have
pets.

24E69C1228EC4824A1CCC14CAD1DA47B.description:
Begin to describe the difference between objects, such as telling that one
doll has a blue dress and the other has a red dress.

651942F95D7049E78319A113A153AD56.description: Recognize and classify things in their environment.

5C1D6FC1D19C48BB802BA184AB2CEAFB.description:
Children begin to develop processes and strategies for classifying
and using data.

E578B41BA81C4068896C1B8F141840A3.description: With support, measure ingredients for making bread.

6E4F5C1B353347339689BC95D5CA21A0.description:
Expand their use of formal measuring tools to include more complex or
detailed tools, such as rulers, kitchen and bathroom scales, thermometers,
etc.

D78E62C85DD84366AA6DD1243BEEFA9E.description:
Use informal measuring tools, such as footsteps, hands, or blocks to
measure length, volume, and other measurable characteristics.

34A2714F3D144921825AAAC80C4D3704.description:
Begin to use formal measuring tools, such as tape measures and balance
scales, to determine size and weight.

9F83CC50AC1549E5931A76E53F09039B.description: Hold a piece of fruit in each hand to decide which is heavier.

57AADA4BD15D4C43B5E236DE127F7F84.description:
Use a cup to move sand into a bucket, counting out loud as they pour each
cupful in, sometimes.

CCD32E468CB643C59973C04E77C28921.description: Use non-standard and standard tools and units of measurement.

976FCD75087444A3B414E1954BE00103.description:
Point out that one book must be “longer” than another one because the
spine is thicker.

6F6CFE23D644494AA675A0C74BAEA6EE.description:
Place blocks tightly against each other to compare the area, or space inside,
two differently sized rectangles, with more accuracy.

9FB55670C6A54449AF6119E95ABFBC05.description:
With prompting, place blocks somewhat randomly inside two differently sized
squares to compare how much space is inside each square (area), with
some accuracy.

1D860B1EB94045498908D73B01935641.description:
Set several blocks next to each other, using trial and error to decide which is
longest, when working to line blocks from longest to shortest.

E7B37A58FF844891A2C9A68FB8288FF9.description:
Compare size with simple terms, such as bigger, smaller, taller, shorter,
lighter, and heavier.

7961492CD0824167AC0CF6B9393813B5.description:
Compare things in their environment and use the language of measurement (lighter, darker, long,
longer, big, bigger, etc.) to describe them.

F43803E3D96F48EE8E45D480554C4831.description: Ask a familiar adult to help them measure string for a bracelet.

5ADEB1D4F7734043B96882DB50399CB6.description:
Participate in a group discussion to decide which shelf will best fit the
wooden unit blocks.

07CAF2C7F3A148BB89155405581FA094.description:
Draw scribbles and spirals both inside and outside the lines when asked to
“color in” or “fill in” a square (early recognition of area).

38B8158FCE5349C7B2C26DAF34F7902D.description:
Notice and recognize that things in their environment can be measured (length/height, weight, area,
volume, temperature, time).

D338575AE7F645ABB2BB4CDFB672BAC9.description: Children show a growing understanding of the concepts of quantifying and comparing.

7D49D808D29B4631AD340D04D6D00D95.description:
Use a mental map of ordering as they set stacking cups in a row from
smallest to largest.

283D585AA78044D8AD55EEF42443A793.description:
Place rods of Unifix cubes in order from shortest to longest based on the
number of individual cubes.

70AFDEC52E3F4E2F84D14910BAF037DF.description:
Set several blocks next to each other, using trial and error to decide which is
longest, when working to line blocks from longest to shortest.

D834BCC0408F4E45A46D1E6A78B97B58.description: Choose picture books from the library that have main characters who look like them.

ABAEFD8246B04CC39D4EAE3EFAAB12EC.description:
Ordering and Seriation: Arrange objects in order according to changes in a specific attribute, such
as size, length, number, color, etc.

FAC0B6CB87B143149F1FB4402258CD08.description:
Begin to copy patterns into other materials. For example: looking at an AAB
pattern made with yellow and blue counting bears, draw that pattern with
yellow and blue crayons.

2640B3895CD140CDA9E40D724494A979.description: Recognize, identify, and build repeating AAB and AABC patterns.

E652FBA9D6FE45A8978FDCC5EF1B8B6C.description: Recognize, identify, and build repeating AB and ABC patterns.

C4E8F87B420A40479FD3D86526998D25.description:
Continue a pattern set out by an adult, adding a triangle and then a circle to
a row of triangle, circle, triangle, circle.

E54820793D584DD09BE87C85B0B466D2.description:
While looking at a pattern of blocks set out by an adult, copy the pattern with
their own set of blocks.

7C82586D26764A6AB82E80E1D2DEBB8B.description:
Put a blue counting bear in the empty spot in a row of yellow bear, blue,
yellow, empty space, yellow.

F33443AC52D6477DA5083C1EFB842AF2.description:
Recognizing and Building Patterns: Notice, recognize, copy, extend, and create repeating
patterns.

78CD9CA57894428685B8201E990381B3.description:
Children show a growing understanding of patterns, structures, and relationships
in math.

CCCE1A07A0224678BE29060FA4BB3D22.description:
Quickly answer questions about the parts of a whole. For example,
recognizing that if there are 3 green blocks and 1 red block, there are 4
blocks, or if there are 6 candies then 3 people can share with 2 candies
each.

64DB9FF5ECAC476CAB1BD261C60ADD99.description:
Begin extending their understanding of equal parts to include 1/4 and 1/3,
such as 4 parts of a sandwich or separating crackers into 3 equal piles.

C4A224FB76974A45AA1AF0443CF9EB2F.description:
Begin to identify “half” of a circle (cookie) or square (sandwich), as well as
“half” of a countable quantity (crackers) as they apply to “fair shares.”

8923CE402C5E4190811303D0B950A1AF.description:
Continue to explore and become more accurate in dividing shapes into equal
parts.

73D78836206E4F54BB9E97E2B3A695F0.description:
Attempt to label a whole and its parts with numbers, such as explaining that
their basket of 4 pieces of play food has 2 pears and 2 oranges.

5B09FE6269E740A9AA35AD08DD2F686F.description:
Begin to use tools to divide playdough shapes (circle, square, or rectangle)
into two or more generally equal parts, through trial and error, and they may
not be able to explain how they decided what was “equal.”

FA09762E9E3B4420B327994DF81F3E24.description:
Recognize that parts make up a whole, and whole is bigger than individual
parts. However, they may not be able to use numbers or measurements to
explain why this is the case.

BE49C7FA405248EBB3285227D3164DE8.description:
Investigate and begin to understand the concept of a whole and how it can be divided into two (or
more) equal parts.

23F40ED39B934A1D80CC26417E7416E9.description:
Use blocks to build taller arches and enclosures/rooms, and begin to build bridges, ramps, stairs,
and add roofs to their constructions.

EA64688185B44181884CE197B32E71BD.description:
Draw a line on a simple illustration of a house to show the separation between a triangle and a
square (identifying and decomposing shapes).

00F1FE8EDE074D71874CBBD9369D8686.description:
Put together simple tangram or pattern block forms, creating new shapes. They may need to
follow a model or map.

16BA022828EF48A4ADD7066AF9D916F1.description:
Use more shapes to add complexity to their drawings, such as using 2 rectangles to form the
upper and lower arm in a drawing of a person.

96F74BE6341B4B1A940D4A71F0597025.description:
Recognize that the faces of 3-dimensional shapes are 2-dimensional shapes, such as identifying
the side of a cube/box as a square.

19583CD09A45415086B895B00BDF12F2.description:
Recognize and identify more complex shapes, such as the trapezoid, rhombus (diamond), and
hexagon, as well as more 3-dimensional shapes, beginning to learn the formal terms for these
shapes.

6B14BC9A4567424F89FD328F62902F87.description:
Recognize lines and angles (corners) as attributes of shapes when comparing and classifying
shapes. For example: noting that a triangle has 3 sides, but a rectangle has 4.

90D7FE8A29F34034B7146702B3E4F3E2.description:
Point out lines and angles as geometric objects, at least in the context of how they can be put
together to form shapes.

D28B6F301CE641998371DEBDA7AB4C25.description:
Begin to build arches and enclosures/rooms with interior space, with more understanding of what
shapes they will need and how to build it.

91E9DA6C66EF423FB4B03D8720BB1D97.description:
Use shapes as parts of their drawings, such as using a square as the body of a house and a
triangle as the roof.

775D57C1D57C4B858A517498FB8D5F65.description: Use blocks to create the lines of a shape, so their creation looks like a particular shape.

634115A4063B4A799177BDA916BBA4F5.description:
Recognize a wider variety of shapes, such as identifying a book cover as a rectangle, and a line
drawn across the angle/corner of a square as forming a triangle.

1D008D9C20774368A553141E5BFD712A.description: Continue to expand the range of shapes they can match, even with size or rotation differences.

4E27986B86274B1E8942EC42AB1E1178.description:
Begin to use blocks to build arches, corners, and enclosures or “rooms,” though the constructions
may not have interior space and may have been constructed through trial and error.

068D75ED84EE424EBB7239B8F6718B24.description: Begin to compare shapes using simple terms, such as being pointy or tall.

3C042D71103B4D17BAFCD6DA19DC702B.description: Identify circles and squares and begin to recognize and identify a sphere (ball) and a cube (box).

F82BC69F7BA8482CAB3D8888B1E4AE2D.description:
Turn two books to line up with each other, so they can check if they are the same shape,
sometimes.

15C7EC853E234A049DBF5B558ECEE880.description:
Match more shapes, such as rectangles, ovals, etc., even if they are different sizes or rotated
differently, such as pointing out two rectangular blocks as matches, even though one was
sideways and the other flat on the floor.

87078CC1F5584D61A308FCC495C8DC11.description: Explore and begin to analyze two-dimensional and three-dimensional shapes and shape attributes.

2E615C9B1B2A424B933F4F5F2B42CC89.description: Quickly decide if puzzle pieces will fit in the spot they are working on.

1F02A546065E4520B5B0275283AA1310.description: Walk around furniture and other people without bumping into them.

D65ACACEC7C04ABF9CEB2909DEE3FFAE.description: Move successfully through a simple obstacle course.

0EF552053050434C8EE076B24F47B786.description:
Label or name some locations during play, such as “That corner is home
base!”

022B644C053041C69163513B74081D40.description:
Keep track of themselves and where they’ve been as they move through a
maze.

A2F5D129E18A4BA29EB210C2A7BB90EC.description:
Begin to build a mental model of a line between dots on a graph to predict
where two “lines” might meet.

59CB0183B78243DDAE2ED46B392A3794.description: Recognize a taller bar in a bar graph means that bar has “more.”

060457878E084BBAA0C3D9C9867CAE79.description:
Continue to expand their spatial and directional vocabulary, including terms
such as left and right, as well as in front of and behind.

E3B41A540E9C49A7885DF2A750152A4F.description: Find a toy that has been misplaced or intentionally hidden.

14727ED4C93F40FF9711F193429D0D0E.description:
Look over puzzle pieces to narrow down the group to just those that might fit
in the space they are trying to fill, without using trial and error for each piece,
sometimes.

8F917F8922EB434F98D8858EA002F0D5.description:
Expand their spatial vocabulary to include more complex terms such as
beside and between.

D5E5FC6B8F764A1EB5C90F5D13ADA58C.description:
Explore and begin to recognize the positional relationships between objects, their environment, and
themselves.

40D4BECE90D4494DA2C50494DB67F157.description: Children show a growing understanding of shapes and spatial relationships.

CD643A7E04BF4EE6B8672ED115982907.description:
Quickly answer questions about the parts of a whole. For example,
recognizing that if there are 3 green blocks and 1 red block, there are 4
blocks, or if there are 6 candies then 3 people can share with 2 candies
each.

A7A00CCBC539481EB66BFE3406A24DE4.description:
Mentally separate larger groups of objects in two or more smaller groups
when figuring out quantity. For example, with a plate of 7 apple slices,
visually separate into groups of 3 and 4 to be able to easily decide there are
7 slices.

303EF46BFBC142A58C03B913DE78F574.description:
Recognizes and produces number combinations up to 4. For example,
moving a collection of four toy cars to groups of 1 and 3, 2 and 3, 3 and 1, 4
and 0.

2981A3E1442746A59CF1052ED0084394.description:
Attempt to label a whole and its parts with numbers, such as explaining that
their basket of 4 pieces of play food has 2 pears and 2 oranges.

C4ABEF78AFAD43EE90E5396C5DAFF732.description: Trade 2 small items for 1 bigger item.

FD149AF1ACDD4A4E9841F7ADA916E68B.description:
Recognize that parts make up a whole, and whole is bigger than individual
parts. However, they may not be able to use numbers or measurements to
explain why this is the case.

AAA48882D194447395C081AE9C9FB28A.description:
Composing and Decomposing Numbers: Begin to understand that numbers are made up of
smaller numbers.

6369B14C8DE24A2AA4B2E5687E405C77.description: Tell how many children are present after counting how many are absent.

8B330285ED714F3EB7EEC4EDF27AE42F.description:
Mentally separate larger groups of objects in two or more smaller groups
when figuring out quantity. For example, with a plate of 7 apple slices,
visually separate into groups of 3 and 4 to be able to easily decide there are
7 slices.

86EEC8FD05434446BF673DDAA308A4B9.description:
Use finger patterns, objects, and counting on to join quantities together. For
example, when prompted with “You have 7 cheese sticks, and someone
gives you 5 more. How many do you have now?” will start at 7 and counting
8, 9, 10, 11, 12 until they have counted 5 more numbers to find the sum.

8BF49CE24E484085A5829DA8517472FF.description:
After naming who is missing during the morning message, tell how many
children are absent today.

3801DDB46E594B6EA6F559A780AE4E2D.description: Tell how many children are present after counting how many are absent.

777275D5B869494FB4D2807DC31483D9.description: Say that William has more blocks than they do, after counting.

FF673BC1D3BA432F978078DEECAA38C9.description:
Look at the two pieces of crackers on their plate, compare that with the three
on Laura’s plate and say, “I need one more.”

284CA40E52EC4D50AD7502E30DC4B52F.description: Choose the biggest piece of cake.

927A168761D249F48067C5263013A2E9.description:
Tell who is first and who is second in a race or other scenario. For example,
“Sarah finished her snack first, and I finished second.”

26B9704A88A84E87B533AD852B8744A6.description:
Comparing, Adding, and Subtracting Numbers: Begin to understand numbers as sets to be
compared, put together, and taken apart.

9A1BA95F72DC496787A08F83AEA90E38.description:
Mentally separate a large group of objects into two or more smaller groups.
For example, recognizing that they have five blueberries, and their sister
also has five, so there are ten blueberries in all.

F55F569F99C24D0E8CABC95445FBB444.description:
Recognize some common number arrangements, such as 5 and 5 makes
10.

B3080B2EC0274367A6AFB821C9A782C2.description:
Demonstrate “conceptual subitizing,” or identifying a whole when only seeing
parts of it. For example, seeing five cookies stacked and overlapped on a
plate and saying that they see five.

3C9A7892C0254A0B8A4458A39A2BEA06.description:
Recognize that they have five counting bears, and their friend has four, so
they have more than their friend.

C1732C6BF36F4AB886E6D9A5442FC42E.description: Tell a familiar adult that there are “only two” Goldfish crackers on their plate after looking but not counting.

806AF4DCE39D433EA503F71179A1F366.description: Subitizing: Recognize and name the quantity of objects in a group without counting.

EA263C02E92E45CC89A1092B3CECE995.description:
Keep track of what they counted and what they haven’t counted in a group of
objects.

27223869EB15483FA2AB6F7FB0E428B1.description:
Show an understanding of cardinality, or the understanding that the last number
said when counting is the total quantity. For example: counting the cards in their
hand, and saying, “I have six cards.”

72934D5B87224F93B9DBE5027E890783.description: Pass out ten crackers for each child.

EED28EF0D0BB4D749DD99AAB13BAC1B4.description:
While pretending to launch a rocket, count backwards 5,4,3,2,1 and then shout,
“BLAST OFF!”

4953809C90B8424A845C3BE11987C647.description: Pass out one plate and one cup to each child.

AB3721DB2B6844D4A445A88DCD46EAC8.description: Roll a die that lands on 5, then move their game piece five spaces.

EA0B8C257EFB4450B667E55E87DB600A.description: Serve themselves five carrot sticks for snack.

C2471BCDCB9043BA96B4F0D71FFE7CC9.description: Point to animal counters one-by-one, counting out loud from one to five.

87E1065983934FD597253725AB9D0ADB.description:
Counting: Explore numbers and number vocabulary with increasing understanding of their
relationship to quantity.

D5B1385BF5B245FE9319A3913CA92156.description: Children show a growing understanding of the concept of number and quantity.

631E9AA7875E4BCD86A5B7E56A89E87A.description:
When their first idea for a solution doesn’t work, try to think of other ways to
solve their problem or achieve the result they want. For example: when the
mosaic tiles they chose for their city artwork are too heavy for the paper, tell
a familiar adult they might need to choose something else to work with, or
different paper, or maybe even different glue to make it stick better.

FD32A620863342F29E1C18FEF31790A5.description:
Share several ideas with another child about how to keep their block tower
from falling.

0678DEE3C8D542E4A2DE036BC2277666.description:
Stack blocks in several ways until they figure out how to make the tower stay
up.

AB583B10E50A42C696D026A823A6BB69.description:
Try to put a bead on a shoelace as a bracelet, and then look around for
other options to replace the shoelace when the bead doesn’t fit.

84F1B77C9B0D46748B7528D60EBDB510.description:
With support, explain how they decided that each child would get two
crackers from the snack tray. For example, by passing out one cracker to
each child, and then counting to make sure that there were enough left for
every child to have one more.

3C04BBEE09BD42F6B86C5BF6FFA0C35D.description:
Plan ways to solve problems based on their knowledge and experience,
such as getting a stool to reach a book that is on a shelf after trying to reach
it on tiptoes.

CF83BD3DECF349DC83A4F035744D013C.description:
With support and modeling, explain their thinking when trying to solve
problems, such as telling a familiar adult that they couldn’t put a toy back
together themselves, so now they are asking for help.

009DD9933A434F20A7C1D7DCB7D50F6A.description:
Try to fix things that are broken, such as putting a toy back together or using
tape to repair a torn paper.

D336B6205B864A9D9998E4E82DECBB1D.description:
Use a variety of strategies to solve problems, such as trial and error, simple
tools, or asking someone to help.

CE85C78278B84EBDA97C0B6E96239C16.description:
Develop an increasing ability to recognize mathematical problems in everyday situations at home
and in the learning environment, and experiment to find possible solutions.

17E1C74F36EF429C90B8651CE700CB04.description:
Begin expressing simple mathematical problems identifying mathematical
symbols such as “+” or “=.”

A628E949CDFC4B788D78FA90EF5A4C22.description:
Recognize different ways to represent number such as tally marks, dice,
5/10 frames, and numerals.

869CB69707E8483080E64E3B69120FF3.description:
Use mathematical terms like bigger/smaller than, more/less than or the
same when referring to quantities or size of items.

2C812E23FFB64374A2B2B438499EC2C2.description: Estimate how many toy frogs they think are in a plastic pond.

8F07833D035E4BB3A7D0051E675823ED.description:
Participate in a group activity to predict what will happen to a toy car if the
ramp is taller or shorter.

8FE11AF1C44E487C9953D6D6C07EDC6F.description: Tell about how they put a puzzle together.

15531213311446CEBE5289D2401BFFE2.description:
Point out pictures in book that resemble familiar shapes (e.g., sun/circle;
roof/triangle; truck/rectangle).

339782BD173B454BA1D21AE72A1F3EFF.description: Match numeral shapes when completing a number puzzle.

47892B9AAB04491D8CE421C13DA65044.description: Point to a clock and ask if it is time for snack.

AA51E2E4E4B34F87B53339B5FE73C97D.description:
Explore and begin to understand mathematical symbols and language in communicating their
explorations and discoveries.

2365D9EA692D46ADB04C33190EF4B4FA.description:
Explain to a friend how they figured out how many musical instruments were needed
so that each child in the group could have two.

0FAD66CF1BEB4B778664EB821B7C605E.description:
Count the children sitting at the table to answer how many napkins are needed for
snack.

27133759A5004B0298F0E9160EDEF438.description:
Use different size blocks, different arrangements, and other strategies to build and
re-build a structure that falls, until achieving their goal.

8D536C93CECB46B98F48C7C7915B8A10.description:
Suggest an idea for sharing when there are a limited number of scoops in the sand
table.

AF2CF3FA3A8442218D5DD1685B28ABA5.description: Make an ‘AB’ pattern using colored manipulatives.

0FA548731D294B30B23B705DDCE65AD6.description: Tell a friend that their birthday is in five days.

FE9135BEFF684C2AA7BEAE61DACC2F1B.description: Sort colored goldfish crackers, then count how many are in each color group.

4C8D6D3BC0A34CAD8D301B8F8CDE62FB.description:
When building with Legos, search for another wheel, while saying “I only have three
wheels.”

0E9926573423447088DF4FB9B4400591.description:
Play with signs, words, and patterns, e.g., Five Little Monkeys or Brown Bear, Brown
Bear, What Do You Hear?

A8E3A0E18D814C0DB9A7406290D79BD6.description: Ask a familiar adult to pour more milk to fill their cup all the way (concept of “more”).

CE5CD94393B14D6394A99EF49BC768EA.description: Ask for “three candles” on their birthday cake.

6D70A55E52884313BF0980223A53E3BB.description: Explore and begin to make sense of their world through mathematical thinking and strategies.

2E95FEB0481C48BCA29E5D9936696CC5.description:
Children begin to develop processes and strategies for solving mathematical
problems.
